text: I think it pull off as well as possible
spare me an artistic dispute over the
provenance of a Jackson Pollock painting
has Pitts traditional ways of
determining whether a work is genuine
against newer technologies so he wasn't
wearing socks right which is a good
thing
Nick Patrick Oh a retired New York City
detective and forensic specialist
believes that if fiber technology and
hair analysis are good enough for
criminal investigations they ought to be
good enough to decide who created a
painting mr. patrero worked with the
estate of Ruth Kligman Pollux then lover
who was with him in 1956 when he died in
a car crash Petrenko compared soil grass
and hair fibers from Pollux estate to
those found in the painting he points to
a polar bear hair plucked from the
painting as his strongest piece of
evidence that rare hair matched a rug
that is still located in the
estate experts and the auction houses
that rely on them maintain that
forensics can point to where and when a
painting was made but only expert
evaluation of composition and
brushstrokes can identify an artist's
unique style the authentication board
set up by the Pollock Krasner Foundation
created by Pollux wife Lee Krasner had
rejected the painting the difference of
opinion could be worth millions of
dollars a Pollock painting was recently
auctioned for 58 million dollars but
without an expert stamp of approval the
painting at the center of the dispute is
likely to fetch no more than $50,000
you
